thread.title: Retail sales fall short of forecasts, down 0.1pc
thread.title_full: Retail sales fall short of forecasts, down 0.1pc | afr.com

author: Primrose Riordan
title: Retail sales fall short of forecasts, down 0.1pc
text:
Household goods retailing led the decline with an outsized 1.9 per cent fall, after a sizeable 2.4 per cent increase the month before. Glenn Hunt Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan Retail sales fell in July for the first time in 14 months, a sign the sharemarket turmoil might have made households more uncertain, and marking a weak start for the economy to the third quarter.
Sales dropped 0.1 per cent from June, when they rose 0.6 per cent, missing economist forecast for a 0.4 increase, the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showed on Thursday.
Household goods retailing led the decline with an outsized 1.9 per cent fall, after a sizeable 2.4 per cent increase the month before.
The rapid deterioration suggests consumers might have brought forward spending because of the government's $20,000 instant asset tax write off for small businesses.
In the May budget Prime Minister Tony Abbott coined the term "Tony's tradies" to describe the big winners, handing small businesses the ability to claim an unlimited number of tax deductions for buying cars and machinery valued at less than $20,000 each.
In July, however, electrical and electronic goods retailing fell by 3.3 per cent and hardware, building and garden supplies retailing dropped by 1.4 per cent.
A separate ABS report showed Australia's trade deficit narrowed in July to $2.5 billion from 3.1 billion in June helped by a 2 per cent rise in exports.
The dollar fell after the news, down to US70.10¢ from around US70.40¢ just before the release.
